bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 10, 1925

div1.p: Laura Carter says that she is withholding Russell's letter about possible yellow fever cases because of Henry Carter's poor health.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 10, 1925
div1.opener:
Keep - Re work on
book during latter part of
Father's life
/LC
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 10, 1925.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Father had a decided turn for the worse last Sunday, and although
he has pulled up somewhat, I am still--in the absence of instructions
to the contrary from yourself--holding up your letter (with enclos-
ures) concerning the suspicious cases in the Parahyba district.

He is using every available particle of time and strength in his
endeavor to complete the 2nd. part of Section 111. and, as I wrote
you before, I don't want to get him “off the track” unless you re-
gard it as essential to the present yellow fever work.

He has finished the straight dictation for Part 2. which I've
been transcribing (on black coffee and strychnia) late at night and
early in the morning, and we are now going over this MSS together
and getting it in shape for the final copying. In this, in spite of
his weakness, he is showing all his old enthusiasm and grasp of the sub-
ject. Of course, its a great strain, but its not a waste, its a jus-
tifiable expenditure of human material (himself and myself)--as much
so as in war time-- for the book--even so far as we have gone--will
have illuminated the subject of yellow fever as has never been done
before. That is, its a constructive thing and should be of use long
long
-2-
after our day--i. e. “worth more than what's left of us”--of the "junior
anyway.

I want you then, instead of regretting the physical stress (as
I know you're doing) only tobbe glad that the thing is already saved
in posse and join me in the hope that he may be able to “hold on” at
least until we have sent you the completed MSS, which--if all goes
even as well as at present--wshould be at no distant day.

With very best remembrances to yourself and Miss Read, as well
as to Dr. Vincent, Dr. Rose and any other of our good friends you
may chance to see.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter.
